channel.title: IRC Functionality

item.title: IRC Functionality
item.dc:creator: @CodeForFame CodeForFame
item.description:
@CodeForFame wrote:

[quote=“KO9, post:40, topic:396713”][quote author=CodeForFame link=topic=493882.msg3615191#msg3615191 date=1306898655]

You need to be identified to Nickserv before Chanserv knows you’re genuine, otherwise you would need to type a password to be the owner, and I’ve never seen an IRC network where every Owner, OP, HOP, Voice (etc) needs their own password… That would suck.

That’s just not true at all, see Quakenet, EFnet, EnterTheGame, etc.
[/quote]

You already stated QN and EFNet don’t use nickserv… EFNet doesn’t even have any services at all.[/quote]

I know… Read more carefully.

Read full topic

You need to be identified to Nickserv before Chanserv knows you’re genuine, otherwise you would need to type a password to be the owner, and I’ve never seen an IRC network where every Owner, OP, HOP, Voice (etc) needs their own password… That would suck.
[/quote]

That’s just not true at all, see Quakenet, EFnet, EnterTheGame, etc.[/quote]

You already stated QN and EFNet don’t use nickserv… EFNet doesn’t even have any services at all.

Read full topic

item.title: IRC Functionality
item.dc:creator: @CodeForFame CodeForFame
item.description:
@CodeForFame wrote:

[quote=“Ecko, post:38, topic:396713”][quote author=CodeForFame link=topic=493882.msg3616568#msg3616568 date=1307036238]
No good networks, are you kidding me? The biggest networks are like that.[/quote]
LOL. Name a big network with it turned on. Doubt you will even answer this request.

No, the feature isn’t turned off, it’s not implemented at all, which is why it’s outdated. You really are mentally retarded if you think that it’s fully implemented, but just turned off…

And you would know this… because you saw the the configuration for the services package all the IRC networks use. Yeah, that makes more fucking sense than it being turned off. Stick to flaming people and leave the logic to those who haven’t had their brains addled by God knows what.[/quote]

Off the top of my head, Freenode has the optional parameter to identify, and it’s runing an outdated version of Nickserv. Again, it’s not ‘turned off’ it’s not implemented, because it’s an old version. OpenJoke, DarkSin, SwiftIRC and Mibbit all support it. Those are just a few, and I’m sure I could find quite a few more… The only reason the top 5 or so aren’t listed, is because they don’t have Nickserv (gee I wonder how they function without Nickserv…).

I’ve never claim to have seen he configuration files… You’re making random ass statements again. Most IRC daemons are open source, and you can see what options they have. For example, Freenode does not have the option to enable/disable immediate killing, all you can do is set the delay before the nick is changed. Some flavors do have the option to turn it off, but why the hell would you disable sole purpose of Nickserv?

So, how about you actually start bringing substance to the debate rather than outright making things up, and just saying ‘nuh-uh’. Go find some big networks that have actually specifically turned it off, then try arguing some more.

Read full topic

No, the feature isn’t turned off, it’s not implemented at all, which is why it’s outdated. You really are mentally retarded if you think that it’s fully implemented, but just turned off…

And you would know this… because you saw the the configuration for the services package all the IRC networks use. Yeah, that makes more fucking sense than it being turned off. Stick to flaming people and leave the logic to those who haven’t had their brains addled by God knows what.

item.title: IRC Functionality
item.dc:creator: @CodeForFame CodeForFame
item.description:
@CodeForFame wrote:

[quote=“Ecko, post:36, topic:396713”][quote author=CodeForFame link=topic=493882.msg3614739#msg3614739 date=1306876749]
You identify before you change your nick… The nickname is an optional parameter, which you’re forced to use when you have it instantly kill the person.[/quote]
… So then you would have to connect with either a different nick, or use a client that allows you to identify to NickServ. This is why no good networks even have the optional parameters for NickServ.

You’re right, because ‘/nickserv set kill on’ is the default option. You would either use ‘/nickserv set kill immed’ or ‘/nickserv set protect kill’. Nickserv’s that don’t have one of those two (or the equivalent) are outdated, and pretty pointless, because anyone can use your nick for some time. People using your nick at all completely defeats the purpose of having Nickserv.

What great logic. If a feature is turned off, then that means it is outdated. You really are the epitome of all that is genius.[/quote]

No good networks, are you kidding me? The biggest networks are like that.

No, the feature isn’t turned off, it’s not implemented at all, which is why it’s outdated. You really are mentally retarded if you think that it’s fully implemented, but just turned off…

Read full topic

… So then you would have to connect with either a different nick, or use a client that allows you to identify to NickServ. This is why no good networks even have the optional parameters for NickServ.

CodeForFame:

You’re right, because ‘/nickserv set kill on’ is the default option. You would either use ‘/nickserv set kill immed’ or ‘/nickserv set protect kill’. Nickserv’s that don’t have one of those two (or the equivalent) are outdated, and pretty pointless, because anyone can use your nick for some time. People using your nick at all completely defeats the purpose of having Nickserv.

What great logic. If a feature is turned off, then that means it is outdated. You really are the epitome of all that is genius.

Read full topic

item.description:
@CodeForFame wrote:

[quote author=CodeForFame link=topic=493882.msg3614739#msg3614739 date=1306876749]People using your nick at all completely defeats the purpose of having Nickserv.

No it doesn’t, it’s used for channel privileges and so on…[/quote]

That’s what Chanserv is for…

How do you think networks without Nickserv have channel privileges and such?

Read full topic

item.title: IRC Functionality
item.dc:creator: @CodeForFame CodeForFame
item.description:
@CodeForFame wrote:

[quote=“Ecko, post:27, topic:396713”][quote author=CodeForFame link=topic=493882.msg3614416#msg3614416 date=1306861830]

Because that means he can never set it up…

You’d have at least 20 seconds before it kills…
Give up…

Maybe on the MoparScape network… Most networks let you set it so that you need to identify before you set that as your nick, otherwise you’re killed instantly. Also, I don’t see the network that’s being used anywhere in the code that was posted.

… That is not how most networks work (EnterTheGame, Quakenet, rizon, freenode, EFnet, Gamesurge). If you have nick protection on, then there’s 20 seconds to identify to NickServ before having the name changed automatically. Otherwise anyone can stay on a nick until the owner uses the ghost command to kick them off. The proper way of doing this is checking if the user is identified (http://www.moparisthebest.com/smf/index.php/topic,493882.msg3611589.html#msg3611589).

Yes, with the default settings, I’m saying change the default settings, and set protection to kill. Furthermore, EnterTheGame, Quakenet, Gamesurge, and EFnet do not use Nickserv, so take your bullshit elsewhere.
[/quote]
Well I haven’t used any of those networks for almost 4 years, so you can take your asshole attitude and fuck off.

That leaves Rizon, and Freenode. Both are using extremely outdated/custom nick services.

Outdated? What IRC service package are they using then, since I doubt you even know.

Most networks (from what I’ve seen) that have Nickserv allow you to set kill to immed (immediate), or protect to kill; both of those kill the person as soon as they set their nick and aren’t registered with Nickserv. Not having that functionality completely defeats the purpose of having any form of nick protection.

… So once someone sets their nick to one with protection, they will never be able to identify because NickServ will kill/force name change immediately. That makes complete and total sense. Most networks with NickServ give a certain amount of time before killing an unidentified protected nick. ‘/ns set kill on’ does not “kill the person as soon as they set their nick and aren’t registered with NickServ”.[/quote]

If you don’t know what you’re talking about then fuck off. You clearly made shit up just to sound like you know what you’re talking about, and I knew you were wrong; get over it.

The entire package they use is completely irrelevant. The only relevant part is Nickserv, and it’s easy to tell that it’s outdated/custom because they are lacking functionality, and have entirely unique ‘commands’.

You identify before you change your nick… The nickname is an optional parameter, which you’re forced to use when you have it instantly kill the person.

You’re right, because ‘/nickserv set kill on’ is the default option. You would either use ‘/nickserv set kill immed’ or ‘/nickserv set protect kill’. Nickserv’s that don’t have one of those two (or the equivalent) are outdated, and pretty pointless, because anyone can use your nick for some time. People using your nick at all completely defeats the purpose of having Nickserv.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @Ecko Ecko
item.description:
@Ecko wrote:

[quote=“CodeForFame, post:26, topic:396713”][quote author=Ecko link=topic=493882.msg3613485#msg3613485 date=1306792592]

Because that means he can never set it up…

You’d have at least 20 seconds before it kills…
Give up…

Maybe on the MoparScape network… Most networks let you set it so that you need to identify before you set that as your nick, otherwise you’re killed instantly. Also, I don’t see the network that’s being used anywhere in the code that was posted.

… That is not how most networks work (EnterTheGame, Quakenet, rizon, freenode, EFnet, Gamesurge). If you have nick protection on, then there’s 20 seconds to identify to NickServ before having the name changed automatically. Otherwise anyone can stay on a nick until the owner uses the ghost command to kick them off. The proper way of doing this is checking if the user is identified (http://www.moparisthebest.com/smf/index.php/topic,493882.msg3611589.html#msg3611589).
[/quote]

Yes, with the default settings, I’m saying change the default settings, and set protection to kill. Furthermore, EnterTheGame, Quakenet, Gamesurge, and EFnet do not use Nickserv, so take your bullshit elsewhere.[/quote]
Well I haven’t used any of those networks for almost 4 years, so you can take your asshole attitude and fuck off.

CodeForFame:

That leaves Rizon, and Freenode. Both are using extremely outdated/custom nick services.

Outdated? What IRC service package are they using then, since I doubt you even know.

CodeForFame:

Most networks (from what I’ve seen) that have Nickserv allow you to set kill to immed (immediate), or protect to kill; both of those kill the person as soon as they set their nick and aren’t registered with Nickserv. Not having that functionality completely defeats the purpose of having any form of nick protection.

… So once someone sets their nick to one with protection, they will never be able to identify because NickServ will kill/force name change immediately. That makes complete and total sense. Most networks with NickServ give a certain amount of time before killing an unidentified protected nick. ‘/ns set kill on’ does not “kill the person as soon as they set their nick and aren’t registered with NickServ”.

Read full topic

item.title: IRC Functionality
item.dc:creator: @CodeForFame CodeForFame
item.description:
@CodeForFame wrote:

[quote=“Ecko, post:24, topic:396713”][quote author=CodeForFame link=topic=493882.msg3613392#msg3613392 date=1306786815]

Because that means he can never set it up…

You’d have at least 20 seconds before it kills…
Give up…

Maybe on the MoparScape network… Most networks let you set it so that you need to identify before you set that as your nick, otherwise you’re killed instantly. Also, I don’t see the network that’s being used anywhere in the code that was posted.
[/quote]
… That is not how most networks work (EnterTheGame, Quakenet, rizon, freenode, EFnet, Gamesurge). If you have nick protection on, then there’s 20 seconds to identify to NickServ before having the name changed automatically. Otherwise anyone can stay on a nick until the owner uses the ghost command to kick them off. The proper way of doing this is checking if the user is identified (http://www.moparisthebest.com/smf/index.php/topic,493882.msg3611589.html#msg3611589).[/quote]

Yes, with the default settings, I’m saying change the default settings, and set protection to kill. Furthermore, EnterTheGame, Quakenet, Gamesurge, and EFnet do not use Nickserv, so take your bullshit elsewhere.

That leaves Rizon, and Freenode. Both are using extremely outdated/custom nick services.

So, you’ve listed two networks that don’t have it… Congrats.

Most networks (from what I’ve seen) that have Nickserv allow you to set kill to immed (immediate), or protect to kill; both of those kill the person as soon as they set their nick and aren’t registered with Nickserv. Not having that functionality completely defeats the purpose of having any form of nick protection.

Read full topic

If you have nick protection on, then there’s 20 seconds to identify to NickServ before having the name changed automatically. The proper way of doing this is checking if the user is identified (http://www.moparisthebest.com/smf/index.php/topic,493882.msg3611589.html#msg3611589).

item.title: IRC Functionality
item.dc:creator: @CodeForFame CodeForFame
item.description:
@CodeForFame wrote:

[quote=“mhp, post:20, topic:396713”][quote author=CodeForFame link=topic=493882.msg3611431#msg3611431 date=1306625627]

[quote]public boolean isAdmin(String sender) {
if ((sender.equalsIgnoreCase(“Kryptix”) || sender.equalsIgnoreCase(“Pyru”)) && isOp(sender))
return true;
return false;
}[/quote]
Really? Anyone of the other ops could shut the server down because of this

Are you retarded?

The senders name needs to be Kryptix or Pyru (case doesn’t matter), and be opped.

Also, this looks extremely similar to the IRC class that was in the RSCA source…

Inb4 an op does /nick Pyru or Kryptix, retard…

Learn how to use Nickserv properly… Set protect to high or kill…
[/quote]
Pyru has no nick protection at all… Good fight…[/quote]

Because that means he can never set it up…

Read full topic
